chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The XML plugin provides a number of features that make editing XML and HTML files easier:

listitem.para: On-the-fly validation of XML files
Display of the element tree in a dockable window
Matching tag highlighting
One click insertion of tags and entities
Graphical editing of tags and attributes
A number of miscellaneous commands

chapter.title: Locating DTDs and completion info
chapter.para: To be able to validate XML files and do tag and entity completion in XML and HTML files, the XML plugin must be able to locate either a DTD, or a completion info file. The former can be used for both validation and completion; the latter for completion only.
The XML plugin is bundled with the following DTDs and completion files; to edit these file types, no extra configuration is necessary:

listitem.para: HTML and XHTML
Jakarta Ant build.xml
XSL stylesheets
XML schemas
DocBook-XML 1.4.2 documents
DTDs supplied with jEdit for edit modes, action lists, and so on - useful for edit mode and plugin development

chapter.para: With other XML files, the XML plugin tries to load the file's DTD; you will need to ensure that the DTD is installed and the catalog file is made available to the XML plugin. Catalogs to search in can be specified in the XML>Catalogs pane of the Utilities>Global Options dialog box.

sect1.title: Loading DTDs from the network
sect1.para: If an XML file specifies a DTD using a system ID and the system ID was not found in the catalogs, the XML plugin will not attempt to load the DTD from the network. This is done for two reasons:

listitem.para: Loading from the network every time the buffer needs to be parsed is slow.
It is a privacy concern; someone can send you an XML file containing an embedded system ID pointing to their machine, and use this to track your IP address when you view the file.

sect1.para: While it is recommended you obtain the relevant DTDs, install them locally and set up the catalog accordingly, if you absolutely must load DTDs from a network you can enable this in the XML>General pane of the Utilities>Global Options dialog box.

chapter.title: Parsing XML and HTML
chapter.para: The XML plugin automatically parses XML and HTML files when they are loaded or saved. Optionally, they can also be parsed on the fly, but this uses a fair bit of memory and processor power so it is disabled by default. The current buffer can be parsed at any other time by clicking the parse button in the XML tree window, or using the Plugins>XML>Parse XML Buffer.

XML files are validated, while HTML files are not. Any errors found while parsing XML are handled by the ErrorList plugin; in other words, they are highlighted in the text area, and shown in the Plugins>Error List>Error List window. See the documentation for the ErrorList plugin for details.
If a DTD or XML schema is available, it will be used to validate the XML file; otherwise, only minimal error checking will be performed.

chapter.title: The XML tree window
chapter.para: Plugins>XML>XML Tree displays all elements defined in the current buffer in a dockable window. This window is floating by default, but it can be docked into the view in the Docking pane of the Global Options dialog box.

Clicking on an element in the tree will move the caret to its location in the text area; conversely, moving the caret in the text area will select the corresponding element in the tree. Double-clicking on an element will show the Edit Tag dialog box; see .

If the XML tree window is docked into the current view, hovering the mouse over an element will display all attributes of that element in the view's status bar. If you want attributes to be displayed in the tree itself, you can specify so in the XML>General pane of the Utilities>Global Options dialog box.

chapter.title: Moving around XML and HTML files
chapter.para: If the caret is positioned on a tag, the corresponding opening or closing tag will be highlighted in the text area. You can disable this feature, or change the tag highlight color in the XML>General pane of the Utilities>Global Options dialog box.
Plugins>XML>Go to Matching Tag moves the caret to the corresponding opening or closing tag.
Plugins>XML>Go to Previous Tag moves the caret to start of the previous tag.
Plugins>XML>Go to Next Tag moves the caret to start of the next tag.

chapter.title: The XML insert window
chapter.para: Plugins>XML>XML Insert displays the XML insert window. This window is floating by default, but it can be docked into the view in the Docking pane of the Global Options dialog box.
This window lists elements that may be inserted at the caret position, all declared entities, and IDs (element attributes with a value type of ID).

Clicking an element in the list will insert it into the buffer and show the Edit Tag dialog box for specifying attributes. See for information about the Edit Tag dialog box. Clicking an element with the right mouse button will insert it in the text area, but the Edit Tag dialog box will not be shown.

If text is selected, each selection is wrapped in a pair of opening and closing tags. This is a very powerful feature; you can select any number of text chunks, and surround them with tags, all sharing a common set of attributes.

chapter.title: Tag and entity completion
chapter.para: If the less-than symbol (<) is typed and no other key is pressed within a specified delay (half a second by default), a tag list popup will be shown. Note that only tags which are the parent element is allowed to contain are listed. The arrow keys can be used to select a tag; if you start typing a tag name, only tags whose names begin with the already-entered text will be shown.
Pressing Space or > will insert the currently selected tag into the buffer. Pressing Enter will insert the tag and show the Edit Tag dialog box; see .
Entity completion works in a similar manner; typing & will show an entity list popup. Pressing Space, Enter or ; will insert the currently selected entity into the buffer.
An element or entity completion popup can also be shown by invoking the Plugins>XML>Complete Element or Entity command.
Typing </ will automatically close the last open tag.
Another convenience feature that is disabled by default inserts a closing tag when you finish typing an opening tag.
These features can be enabled, disabled and configured in the XML>Completion pane of the Utilities>Global Options dialog box.

chapter.title: The Edit Tag dialog box
chapter.para: The Edit Tag dialog box can be opened in one of several ways:

listitem.para: Invoking Plugins>XML>Edit Tag at Caret.
Double-clicking a tag in the text area while holding down Control.
Double-clicking on a tag in the XML Tree window (for information about this window see ).

chapter.para: The dialog box lists all declared attributes for the current tag in a table. The columns of the table are as follows:

formalpara.title: Set
formalpara.para: A check box that controls if the attribute is specified or not. Required attributes are always specified.

formalpara.title: Type
formalpara.para: This will either be text or choice. If the attribute is required, required will be appended.

formalpara.title: Value
formalpara.para: For text attributes, this is a text field. For choice attributes, this is a combo box. Depending on the DTD, some attributes might define a default value.

listitem.para: Note that special characters entered in the text field are automatically converted to entities if necessary.

chapter.para: The Preview text field shows what the tag will look like with all currently-specified attributes. Clicking OK will insert the tag into the buffer.

chapter.title: Miscellaneous commands
chapter.para: The following commands can be helpful when editing XML and HTML files.
Plugins>XML>Characters to Entities converts special characters to entities in the current selection.
Plugins>XML>Entities to Characters converts entities to characters in the current selection.
Plugins>XML>Close Last Open Tag inserts a closing tag for the last opened tag.
Plugins>XML>Remove All Tags removes all tags from the current buffer, leaving only text.

Plugins>XML>Split Tag splits the current tag at the cursor, and creates a new tag at the same level. This is useful when editing HTML, Docbook or similar documents for inserting many

or tags. Works hard to match the current indenting style.
Plugins>XML>Parse XML has the same effect as clicking the parse button in the XML tree window.
Plugins>XML>Parse XML on Keystroke is a checkbox menu item that toggles on-the-fly parsing, for the current buffer only.

chapter.title: Using the XML parser in other plugins
chapter.para: The jEdit core only includes a very simple, non-validating and non SAX-compliant parser known as Ælfred. The XML plugin includes and uses the much better Xerces XML parser, from xml.apache.org. If you are developing your own plugin that needs to handle XML, you might prefer to use Xerces over the default jEdit parser.
If you would like to use this parser from your own plugin, you will first need to change your plugin's license if it is licensed under the GPL. The GPL is not compatible with the Xerces license.
The XML plugin itself is licensed under a modified GPL; this will probably be sufficient for your plugin. Here is the text of the license, embedded in each source file of the XML plugin:

blockquote.para: The XML plugin is licensed under the GNU General Public License, with the following exception:
Permission is granted to link this code with software released under the Apache license version 1.1, for example used by the Xerces XML parser package.

chapter.para: You will also need to add a dependency for the XML plugin in your plugin's property file:
Note that you must replace n with the appropriate number, as dependency properties must have consecutive numbers.

That's all there is to it; you can now use the Xerces parser in your plugin. Xerces includes its own implementations of the JAXP, SAX2 and DOM APIs, so integrating existing code should be relatively easy.
